I confess. I absolutely cannot stand playing this bloody thing, and so I've continued dropping my rating following repeated plays. It is not the theme (I enjoy Goa, Cuba, and other such colonizing/spice trading games). It is not the role selection mechanic (I enjoy Citadels, San Juan, Cuba, and Race for the Galaxy, which also have role selection). It is not the fact that it is a resource management game (most, or at least, many Euros have an RM component). It basically boils down to two things -- do I ever want to play again? No. Could I be talked into it? Maybe *once* more, before declaring that it is a 2, once and for all. (EDIT: I have done so).

The main thing for me is that you *have* to play with other newbies your first game, or it breaks -- playing with a mixed group in this game, because of the left-right binding issues and how much (over)analysis has been done on it ensures that veterans will argue the whole game over who is being benefited by the newbie, and trying to coerce the newbie into taking moves favorable to them. Also, a game in which you must know what all the buildings do in advance to *enjoy* the game is irritating...

Why? Well, one of the main mechanics of PUERTO RICO is not merely choosing actions that benefit you the most, but choosing actions that benefit your opponents the \least\, often specifically the person sitting to your left since they will be acting directly after you (thus you, as a player, have the most agency and control over their next action than anyone else's). In other words, it's as much a game about "blocking" as it is about "acting," an important distinction that newer players don't always grasp right away. Having said that, if you ARE able to get a table of 4 or 5 players with a good (or at least relatively similar) understanding of the game, it's an absolute worm-burner, a bloodbath, and a remarkably tense/enjoyable time. I do recommend drafting your buildings when playing. It takes a little longer, of course, but it gives players even more control over how they want this specific game to play out.

All this means that even small missteps or attempts at creative play can end up handing points over to your neighbors with little recourse from the table, resulting in an overbearing "don't step in the bear traps" atmosphere that I usually associate with Chess-like abstracts or some 18xx games.

Puerto Rico is the classic Euro game that is recognizable by most everyone who's been in the hobby for some time. The merit it receives is certainly warranted, as the game remains one of the tightest action-selection and efficiency games out there, creating tons of gameplay space with reasonably simple and streamlined rules. Strategy, timing, and careful planning are absolutely necessary for success here, and considering how one's actions affect the players acting after you is beyond important. Multiple viable strategies exist, and there's plenty of room for players to learn how to navigate these various paths efficiently. It's a game that remains engaging and tense up until the very end and manages to be a game that knows exactly what it wants to accomplish, doing so wonderfully. Not everything about the game is perfect, however, with the graphic design and overall theming being reasonably lacking, but it still holds up even despite these features. Additionally, because of the importance of timing, the game relies heavily on equally-skilled players to make a satisfying experience, which can be challenging to find. Overall, Puerto Rice is an exceptional design that really did a lot of work to pioneer the modern game industry, and while I think there are some games that build on the back of it in more interesting ways, I'd still happily revisit this one and hope to do so much more in the future.

Puerto Rico is a very good game that deservedly has had not just a day in the sun, but rather, several years. The basic concept of this game, action selection is, in one sense, shades of everything that happened in the German game industry for the 5 years that followed its publication, as the tile selection that drives the game here is not far removed from the individual action selection that the workers represent in games like Caylus and Agricola.

PR is a heavily tactical game where 2 mainline strategies exist, one, scoring points by shipping goods, the other, scoring points by buying buildings, preferably the large, end game bonus buildings. Despite the fact that these are relatively known quantities, and have been for years, the game is still compelling.

Rating this game is difficult to do now. I haven't played it regularly in years. It was one of the earlier titles that I latched onto, and when I had less than 10 games, it got a hell of a lot of table-time, often 5+ games in a single session, all in a row. My group moved on to the first expansion and crafted a building group that we thought was more interesting using many of those buildings though, and the base game settled at an 8 for me then, though it is a 10 when I can add in the buildings I like from the expansion.

Coming back to this many, many years later; I still really like it and don't know when I'll get enough experience to even get that expansion out or the second one (as it is included in the newer edition I have) again. It's the precursor to a lot of later things that I think still plays well and is just fast and interesting once people know how it works.

Really though, if you haven't played this yet, and if you like Euros at all, then you should just go out and buy it. Seriously, buy it. The game is addictive in the early going, and as long as you avoid the plethora of strategy guides that were published over the years you should get double digit plays out of the base game before it starts to seem scripted, easily. A lot of the burnout talk that you see circulating here is fueled by the option of online play, which meant that some people were playing it literally in excess of 1000 times. Other than traditional games like Go and Chess, and perhaps card games like Tichu and Spades I don't know of any games that can stand up to that sort of rigour, so don't shy away from the title because of that. It is one of the most significant imports from Germany, period, and is justifiably recognized as a modern classic.

Lançado em 2002 por Andreas Seyfarth, *Puerto Rico* é um marco dos jogos de tabuleiro modernos. Combinando mecânicas elegantes e decisões estratégicas, o jogo se destaca como um dos melhores eurogames já criados.

Ambientado na era colonial, cada jogador assume o papel de um governador na ilha de Porto Rico. O objetivo é acumular pontos de vitória por meio da produção e exportação de mercadorias, além da construção de edifícios. A mecânica central gira em torno da escolha de papéis, como "Construtor", "Prefeito" ou "Capitão". Cada papel oferece uma ação específica, e todos os jogadores participam dela, mas quem escolhe ganha um benefício extra. Isso exige planejamento e antecipação das jogadas dos adversários.

A interação entre os jogadores é sutil, mas constante. As escolhas de papéis e ações afetam diretamente as opções disponíveis para os outros, promovendo uma competição estratégica sem confronto direto. A ausência de elementos aleatórios, como dados ou cartas, reforça a ênfase na habilidade e no planejamento.

A rejogabilidade é outro ponto forte. Com diversas estratégias possíveis e a necessidade de se adaptar às ações dos adversários, cada partida oferece uma experiência única. O equilíbrio entre diferentes caminhos para a vitória mantém o jogo desafiador e envolvente.

*Puerto Rico* recebeu inúmeros prêmios e reconhecimentos, incluindo o Deutscher Spiele Preis e o International Gamers Award. Por anos, liderou o ranking do BoardGameGeek, consolidando sua posição como um clássico.

Em resumo, *Puerto Rico* é um jogo que combina profundidade estratégica, mecânicas bem elaboradas e alta rejogabilidade. É uma escolha excelente para jogadores que apreciam desafios intelectuais e decisões significativas a cada turno.
